intro: Digitaria didactyla var. peninsulae, commonly known as the Peninsula Digitaria, is a grass species native to specific regions of the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, tufted growth habit and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, spikelet-based inflorescences, which are typical of the Poaceae family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetland or riparian habitats. Its botanical features make it an important component of local ecosystems and a subject of ecological study.
